item.title: Home
item.content:encoded:
Programmer, Entrepreneur, Sailor, Scuba Diver and Aspiring NHL Hockey Player

 

Entrepreneur

Naytev helps brands improve the social sharing running through their page by tracking, customizing and optimizing their share buttons. 

Amazing for blogs, newspapers, politicians, product sales, and really anyone who wants to improve their social branding. Learn what vibes with your customer and optimize to hit that niche.

Go Naytev ›

Programmer

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="588.0"] That's me![/caption]

 Focusing on the Web, I enjoy all aspects of programming and the development process. Over the course of my Career, I've tackled some hard problems and also had some fun with the easy ones. I thank everyone who is responsible for open source and give back to my community when I can.

Portfolio ›

Sailor

 Sailing since I was 9 years old, I have always loved cruising over open water on any wind powered vehicle. Since 2011, I have been a proud owner of a 24' Kells and have been sailing it all over the Chesapeake Bay. 

Sailing ›

item.title: Portfolio
item.content:encoded:
Projects - Big and Small

Naytev

Naytev helps brands optimize their users social sharing through A/B testing different options during the share process. Co-founding the company with three other friends, we have been growing at a rapid pace. I lead the technology team, architecting and developing solutions. 

Current Full Time Project

NPR.org homepage redesign

Built the new npr.org homepage from design to production. Using the latest best practices and tools, I created a front end experience that is responsive and auto-localizes to your current NPR station. Used by millions of people daily, this is the most hit page on NPR.org. Also created the Center Stage experience, a custom ad unit featuring rich content. This was NPR's first foray into native advertising.

 

Nominated for a Webby ( source )

Center Stage in Ad Week ( source )

NPR Audience Intelligence Dashboard

Lead development for the NPR Audience Intelligence Dashboard. Provides insight into how articles perform and how they were shared through social media. Compiles 15 different real-time reports and displays to the user in an easy to digest way. Integrates with Google Analytics, Facebook and Twitter APIs to aggregate information. 

 

Featured in Nieman Journalism Lab ( source )

 

NPR Notifications

Architected and implemented system to deliver Breaking News notifications to all apple products. Built with Scala and Akka, the system delivers about 1.7 million push notifications per breaking news message. Delivers messages to the NPR News iPhone and iPad App, and Safari Web Notifications.

Open Source Projects:

Monad.js ( source ) - A port of some of my favorite Scala monads to Javascript. Brings Options, Eithers and Pattern Matching to both the DOM and Node.js applications. Growing out over the course of use on various websites.

Play-Mongo-SecureSocial ( source ) - A giter8 template to scaffold Play Framework projects that include Mongo and the Secure Social authentication library. Removes much of the boilerplate configuration and set up of any projects needed social logins and storage.

 

Policy Mapping

My only public project during my time at Booz Allen Hamilton, I developed an application to help collect and visual data for the complex environment of governmental policies. 

It allowed users to identify frictions and whitespace between policies so that government agencies can best determine how to operate.

item.title: Sailing
item.content:encoded:
Good Friends Photo Gallery

Living A Dream

Back in 2011, I was lucky enough to receive a boat from one of my Boss's at Booz Allen Hamilton. We were talking over a beer one day after a meeting, and we were discussing what I did prior to Booz. I was a sailing instructor for 5 years, and really enjoyed teaching kids how to sail. He shocked me by offering his boat that has been in storage for the last 7 years.

 

It's always been my dream to own a boat and it has finally become a reality.

item.title: Papito West
item.content:encoded:
As a recent resident new resident of SF and new to the Hayes Valley Neighborhood, it is hard to know what the "neighborhood staples" are. This restaurant may be new( honestly have no idea, but it feels like it), but Papito West is one of my favorites on the busy street. I've been there for a few times over the last few weeks and I'll tell you why.

Papito West is an upscale refined good-old Mexican restaurant. There isn't any funky Mexican fusion dishes or odd spins on classic food, it is only the the basics done very well. All the ingredients are fresh organic and delicious. Let me step you through my classic meal.

First thing is I sit down and grab a gold old fashioned Tecate and lime. It pairs great with the chips and gets me relaxed for the rest of our meal. Chelsea and I always start our meal with the Queso Fundido with Chrizo. To be honest, this may be the best thing on the menu and I have thought about ordering it as my appetizer and my main meal. It's the perfect blend gooey, meaty and crispy. Crisp tomatoes, onions and peppers with amazing blend of cheeses and a ladle or two full of chorizo. By the end of the dish ( which is a nice size by the way, you have gotten a bit in your belly and feeling pretty good. 

By this time, I have finished my first Tecate and on my second, ready for my usual main meal, the Chicken Burrito. 

I know what your thinking, a BURRITO? COMMON!!! Why would you go to an "upscale" place and get a burrito, go to the mission and get a messy one! Well, I'll tell you that it isn't some fancy concoction, or some noble fusion feast, it's just a standard foil wrapped burrito.

When I first got the burrito, I was surprised that I received a Chipotle Log, but once I took a bite I understood. It's just a burrito done well, good ingredients good, nicely cooked, and most importantly nicely rolled. By the time I finished the burrito, I wasn't hoping there there was a side of rice or beans I was just full. This was pleasantly surprising and a different experience than your normal burrito meal. After my first time coming to Papito West, I knew I would be coming back.  

By the end of the night, I was walking out with a stuffed stomach and three beers deep. That is my favorite way of leaving any Mexican joint, I wouldn't want it any other way. 

One note of caution is Papito West is pretty small, so expect to wait a few minutes before getting seated. Luckily the line moves quick so you shouldn't have to wait long. Just post up by the bar and order your first beer.

Seid Score:

Food: 8
Ambiance: 6
Service: 5
Price: Moderate ( $25 Dollar Meal )
WCA(Would Come Again): Yes, most definitly

Papito West
425 Hayes Street
http://www.yelp.com/biz/papito-west-san-francisco-3
item.dc:creator: mbseid@gmail.com

item.title: Pacific Cafe
item.content:encoded:
Last night I visited a cozy little restaurant that had a sign which read "There something Fishy going on". When you first walk into a restaurant that is an odd quote to see but I'll tell you it isn't bad quality Seafood the sign was referring too, just a joke to start off your night. This 50 person place in Outer Richmond embodies a classic upscale seafood restaurant based in the '70's. Open since July 4th 1974,  Pacific Cafe truly brings you back to that classic fine dinning feel. 

 

It all starts when you arrive. First, there are no reservations. Pacific cafe opens at 5:30pm and will seat the mob of people as it can. The line is large, very large. Generally these are the places I hate, but the Host pleases the masses by serving glasses of wine to calm the nerves and brave the wait. I must add its actually pretty good wine too, jug wine but very drinkable if you know what I mean. Every 10 minutes or so, he would come around with 5 full glasses in hand and hand them out to thirsty patrons. I would recommend not coming at the first opening at 5:30 and come around 6:30 or so. A table for 3-4 would only be about an hour wait, and you will all enjoy your free wine, happy hour on the house.

We had a large party, 9 people (1/5 of the total seats available), so our table took around 2 hours to finally get seated. Once we sat, with quite a buzz I must add, we quickly ordered and food was on its way. I ordered a full meal: Pacific Calm Chowder, Caesar Salad, Ahi Tuna and Rice Pilaf.

The Pacific Clam Chowder was a classic reminder to my favorite New England Clam Chowder. It was a similar white broth, but much much thinner. I overheard that it isn't made with heavy cream or any butter. Figures as the San Francisco version is always trying to be much healthier. It came with many large hunks of delicious clams, while not being super potato-y. That is the true sign of a god clam chowder. Overall, I enjoyed it and would definitely order it again.

Ahi Tuna is one of my favorite pieces of Seafood. It was grilled to a perfect rare and served next to a bed of Rice Pilaf. Overall, the fish was good but kind of lacking in the overall flavor department. They serve the Ahi Tuna with the Wasabi Butter on the side. Because Pacific Cafe wanted to really showcase the quality of the Tuna and keep it pure, it was overall lacking as a premier dish. I definitely applaud the effort to keep the fish pure, but next time I would like the Wasabi Butter grilled into the Tuna Steak. The wasabi butter was a nice balance of sweet and spicy, airing on the side of sweet. I ended putting a big schmeer over the entire steak before I ate it. I'm sure this is by design of the chef, but it isn't something I love doing. I tried some of the Crab Cakes from my friend across the table, and thought they were much better flavor wise. 

 

Overall, it was a really great experience. Would eat again, although I would get something different and would make sure I come with a smaller party. I left with a very satisfied belly and a good memory with good friends. 

Seid Score:

Food: 7
Ambiance: 7
Service: 9
Price: Expensive ( $35 plate, but free wine to start )
WCA(Would Come Again): Yes, but not order the same thing
 

 

Pacific Cafe
http://www.pacificcafesf.com/
 7000 Geary Boulevard
item.dc:creator: mbseid@gmail.com

item.title: New City, New Fun
item.content:encoded:
I'm from New York with a 4 year pitstop in Washington, DC. Over the past 3 months, I have transitioned to San Francisco with my lovely girlfriend Chelsea. Being new to a town there are a ton of new places to explore, places to eat and things to do. Things are a bit different on the west cost, I can already feel it. Just being able to see the mountains connect to the oceans is truly a powerful feeling. 

This blog will serve as a chronicle of my explorations in San Francisco. Over the coming year, I'll be sharing my favorite Restaurants, Bars and Activities from around the city. Hopefully you will have much as fun as I will.  Feel free to give a few recommendations along the way, I would love to hear from you. 


With love and cheers!


Mike
item.dc:creator: mbseid@gmail.com
